content.raw: After a 1.4 re-harness. Could not get it out of that situation with other re-harness attempts.
content.html: After a 1.4 re-harness. Could not get it out of that situation with other re-harness attempts.

content.raw:
A restart after a collapse, for unknown reason, of 1.4 resulted in this foot configuration. The harness drop cannot complete because both feet are not on the ground. Repeated restarts of 1.4 failed to dislodge the feet. 

To work properly the re-harness has to repeat the startup harness process which shakes the robot out into a position with all limbs dangling loosely. 

I said it earlier that the re-harness on a skip needed to be under the control of the contestant. The re-harness makes a big change in the flow of actions. Others have said it and I've experienced also, the need to rework code to respond to this last minute decision. It's now leading to further challenges both for the competition software team and the competitors.
content.html:
A restart after a collapse, for unknown reason, of 1.4 resulted in this foot configuration. The harness drop cannot complete because both feet are not on the ground. Repeated restarts of 1.4 failed to dislodge the feet.

To work properly the re-harness has to repeat the startup harness process which shakes the robot out into a position with all limbs dangling loosely.

I said it earlier that the re-harness on a skip needed to be under the control of the contestant. The re-harness makes a big change in the flow of actions. Others have said it and I've experienced also, the need to rework code to respond to this last minute decision. It's now leading to further challenges both for the competition software team and the competitors.

content.raw: @chapulina It would be very useful if the reharnessing went into the initial startup pose rather than the last position before a fall.  Most of the time, Val falls when she gets into some weird position.  It's unfortunate that the reharnessing puts her back into the same weird position.  This would also help with the feet being too close or overlapping on reharness.
content.html: @chapulina It would be very useful if the reharnessing went into the initial startup pose rather than the last position before a fall. Most of the time, Val falls when she gets into some weird position. It's unfortunate that the reharnessing puts her back into the same weird position. This would also help with the feet being too close or overlapping on reharness.

content.raw: While local testing before trying code in the practice session I've seen the robot get hung up so the lowering never completed. Suggest adding a timeout on the lowering process so it retries. That won't fix all the cases, see the photo with the feet caught on the console, but it will clear some of them. It might be able to automatically provide time credit, also.
content.html: While local testing before trying code in the practice session I've seen the robot get hung up so the lowering never completed. Suggest adding a timeout on the lowering process so it retries. That won't fix all the cases, see the photo with the feet caught on the console, but it will clear some of them. It might be able to automatically provide time credit, also.

content.raw:
Just want to say that we see this too, and saw it in what was a rather humorous way during the dry run today.

Essentially, if you fall down, the robot is unusable from that point forward; you have to restart the sim to regain use of the legs.  You can reharness two, three, a zillion times, and the first step you attempt to take results in disaster.  It's not clear exactly why; I have some sense that the robot may have lost it's sense of foot position (i.e. we command a baby step, and Val tries to take a huge step).
content.html:
Just want to say that we see this too, and saw it in what was a rather humorous way during the dry run today.

Essentially, if you fall down, the robot is unusable from that point forward; you have to restart the sim to regain use of the legs. You can reharness two, three, a zillion times, and the first step you attempt to take results in disaster. It's not clear exactly why; I have some sense that the robot may have lost it's sense of foot position (i.e. we command a baby step, and Val tries to take a huge step).

content.raw:
The other problem is the speed of the movement. That causes the robot to go flailing. I just had a pose leaning forward quite a bit to examine the satellite console and did a skip to 1.4. You'd think the robot had been shot from a cannon. 

Could the physics be disabled during the re-harness move and turned back on during the lowering? Maybe hold at the top for a short period to give time for stabilization with the physics on.
content.html:
The other problem is the speed of the movement. That causes the robot to go flailing. I just had a pose leaning forward quite a bit to examine the satellite console and did a skip to 1.4. You'd think the robot had been shot from a cannon.

Could the physics be disabled during the re-harness move and turned back on during the lowering? Maybe hold at the top for a short period to give time for stabilization with the physics on.

content.raw:
Changed this to a blocker. I continually see the robot caught in 'standing' status after a skip. We can't run the competition with this situation. 

The robot has to come down in a decent position not totally discombobulated or hung up on other entities in the landscape. 

Even when it works there is an inordinate amount of blood, sweat and tears spent in creating code to get the robot back into a reasonable stance, especially getting the feet into a decent orientation. 

Go back to the original skip process and only re-harness when fallen.
content.html:
Changed this to a blocker. I continually see the robot caught in 'standing' status after a skip. We can't run the competition with this situation.

The robot has to come down in a decent position not totally discombobulated or hung up on other entities in the landscape.

Even when it works there is an inordinate amount of blood, sweat and tears spent in creating code to get the robot back into a reasonable stance, especially getting the feet into a decent orientation.

Go back to the original skip process and only re-harness when fallen.

content.raw:
I'll echo this, too, about Val not being usable after reharnessing.  I've tried reharnessing a few times, and the first step I try to take she essentially just sits down.  [Here's a video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T3AE5xG3I-0) trying to move the left foot forward only 5cm.

Val seems to drop a few meters in the world frame each time I reharness (looking at /world to /pelvis in TF, shown in picture).  This seems relevant because when reharnessed, the first thing that happens is she stands as tall as she can, hitting the knee joint limits -- she's trying to reach her pelvis position prior to reharnessing, which is now impossible.  She also is trying to reach her previous torso orientation. I'm wondering if this is throwing off the walk controller. ![val_before_after.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3266145333-val_before_after.png)
content.html:
I'll echo this, too, about Val not being usable after reharnessing. I've tried reharnessing a few times, and the first step I try to take she essentially just sits down. Here's a video trying to move the left foot forward only 5cm.

Val seems to drop a few meters in the world frame each time I reharness (looking at /world to /pelvis in TF, shown in picture). This seems relevant because when reharnessed, the first thing that happens is she stands as tall as she can, hitting the knee joint limits -- she's trying to reach her pelvis position prior to reharnessing, which is now impossible. She also is trying to reach her previous torso orientation. I'm wondering if this is throwing off the walk controller.

content.raw:
I found that jiggling Val with the Gazebo location or orientation controls sometimes will break loose a stuck re-harness. Just little jiggle or Val goes ballistic. 

Another datum is that with the pose screwed up Val doesn't respond to the pelvis height topic at times if she's squatting. The controller won't initiate the movement is my guess because it is seeing a pelvis height that is close to the accepted request. But Val is actually lower than the normal startup pose. I jiggled that situation into working but Val never stood up entirely but did duck walked to the finish box before collapsing by stepping off the end. The vision to pelvis transform was off so the calculated walking distance was more than existed.
content.html:
I found that jiggling Val with the Gazebo location or orientation controls sometimes will break loose a stuck re-harness. Just little jiggle or Val goes ballistic.

Another datum is that with the pose screwed up Val doesn't respond to the pelvis height topic at times if she's squatting. The controller won't initiate the movement is my guess because it is seeing a pelvis height that is close to the accepted request. But Val is actually lower than the normal startup pose. I jiggled that situation into working but Val never stood up entirely but did duck walked to the finish box before collapsing by stepping off the end. The vision to pelvis transform was off so the calculated walking distance was more than existed.

content.raw:
My code skipped to 1.4 but Val locked up. Did the 1.4 service call a number of times and Val just twitched but never was elevated by the harness. Locked up on the "switching to high level control"?

Also seen a re-harness end up with the hands caught behind the hips. 

```
#!c++

[Msg] Task [1] checkpoint [4] Restarted
[Msg] [Harness] Received new goal [2.63189 -0.255318 1.257 0 0 -0.785398]
[Msg] Applied penalty time of [90] seconds
[Msg] [Harness | 01:47.772] New goal ... detaching
[Msg] Detaching harness joint
[Msg] [Harness | 01:47.773] Detached ... reattaching
[Msg] [Harness | 01:47.775] Attached ... lowering
[Msg] [Harness | 01:48.428] Lowered ... switching to high level control

```
content.html:
My code skipped to 1.4 but Val locked up. Did the 1.4 service call a number of times and Val just twitched but never was elevated by the harness. Locked up on the "switching to high level control"?

Also seen a re-harness end up with the hands caught behind the hips.

content.raw: I've created pull request #99, which would reset the arm and leg joints after harnessing. I think it might help with this issue.
